channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ghulam Azam, Party Leader Jailed in Bangladesh War Crime, Dies at 91
item.description: A former chief of the Jamaat-e-Islami Party, Mr. Azam’s imprisonment on war crimes charges linked to the 1971 Bangladesh war of independence from Pakistan set off violent protests last year.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Ottawa Gunman’s Radicalism Deepened as Life Crumbled
item.description: A portrait of the gunman shows he was an increasingly troubled, mentally unstable man who initially may have embraced religion not as a political cause, but as an attempt to scaffold a disintegrating life.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL WINES and WILLIAM YARDLEY
item.media:description: An image taken from social media of Michael Zehaf-Bibeau.

item.title: E.U. Greenhouse Gas Deal Falls Short of Expectations
item.description: The varied energy needs and capacity of member nations led to concessions and compromises that experts say watered down an agreement meant to pressure other countries at climate talks in 2015.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: European Union leaders and family members in Brussels on Thursday. Their accord aimed to set the stage for talks next year.

item.title: In French Port City, ‘a Real Psychosis’
item.description: Resentment and fear have swept Calais, France, in the last year amid a new wave of migrants hoping to cross illegally to Britain, which they see as a better place than France to start a new life.
item.dc:creator: By MAÏA de la BAUME

item.title: Israeli Troops Kill Palestinian Teenager in the West Bank, the 2nd in 8 Days
item.description: The Israeli military said the youth had thrown a firebomb onto a main road often used by settlers.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Sunni Militants Draw Iraqi Forces Into Intense Battles on Several Fronts
item.description: Government forces fought for the third straight day to fend off a heavy assault by Islamic State militants on a strategically placed town in Anbar Province.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: U.S. Commander Sees Key Nuclear Step by North Korea
item.description: Gen. Curtis M. Scaparrotti, the top American military leader in South Korea, says he believes the North is capable of making a nuclear weapon small enough to fit atop a ballistic missile.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Mali Reports First Death From Ebola
item.description: A 2-year-old girl, who traveled across two countries while showing symptoms, is the first recorded Ebola death in Mali.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Open Source: Iranian Photojournalist Reportedly Detained After Covering Protest Against Acid Attacks
item.description: Arya Jafari was reported to have been detained over his images of protesters deploring acid attacks on women in Isfahan.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: Thousands of Iranians attended a protest on Wednesday in the city of Isfahan to demand justice for women disfigured in a spate of acid attacks.

item.title: Islamist Party in Tunisia Appears Set to Rebound
item.description: After ceding power to a caretaker government in January, Ennahda enters Sunday’s national legislative elections as a front-runner.
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:description: Supporters of Rachid Ghannouchi, the founder and head of the Ennahda party, at a campaign rally this week in Slimania, Tunisia.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: With Stunts and Vigilante Escapades, a Populist Gains Ground in Ukraine
item.description: Oleh Lyashko, the Radical Party leader, appears poised to gain a significant bloc in Ukraine’s Parliament in Sunday’s elections, tapping into voters’ frustrations over war and a bad economy.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: "Why do people support me? Because they see that I’m the same as they are," said Oleh Lyashko.

item.title: Putin Accuses U.S. of Backing ‘Neo-Fascists’ and ‘Islamic Radicals’
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia unleashed perhaps his strongest diatribe against the United States yet.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: Speaking in Sochi, Russia, to a panel of Russia experts, President Vladimir V. Putin, center, blamed the United States for prompting the recent crises in Ukraine and the Middle East.

item.title: 31 Egyptian Soldiers Are Killed as Militants Attack in Sinai
item.description: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi convened an emergency meeting of Egypt’s top generals and declared a state of emergency in parts of Sinai, including a curfew.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: World Briefing: Pakistan: Court Acquits a Suspect Charged in the Murder of Daniel Pearl
item.description: A Pakistani court on Friday acquitted one of the main suspects in the 2002 murder of the American journalist Daniel Pearl.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: World Briefing: Turkey: MERS Virus Case Is Reported
item.description: The potentially fatal MERS virus that originated in Saudi Arabia two years ago has spread to Turkey for the first time, the World Health Organization said Friday.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: Dominican Republic: Inmates Riot at Model Prison and Try a Mass Escape
item.description: At least four inmates were killed and several wounded after an attempted mass escape at a prison in San Cristobal, officials said Friday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Libya: Army Advances in Benghazi
item.description: The Libyan Army and its allies among local militias have taken control of one of the largest camps of Islamist forces in the eastern city of Benghazi, military officials said Friday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Austria: Monument Honors Deserters From the Third Reich’s Army
item.description: Austria unveiled a new monument on Friday dedicated to thousands of Austrians who deserted from the German Army during World War II.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Britain: Elizabeth R. Sends First Tweet
item.description: Queen Elizabeth II sent her first tweet on Friday, although she kept things traditional by signing off as “Elizabeth R.”
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: ‘The Storm of Reality’: Chinese Poetic Voices From the Lower Tier of Society
item.description: Reacting to a far more complicated, and in some ways tougher, reality than when a last wave of poetry caught public attention in the 1980s, new voices are emerging from China’s working class.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Shangguan Nanhua, with his family in Beijing at the poetry awards, where he won first prize for his anthology "Eights Beats of the Ganzhou Song."

item.title: News Analysis: Attacks in West Raise New Fears Over ISIS’ Influence
item.description: Analysts say the far-flung plots and attacks are a change in the nature of the group and its threat to the West.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Body of Nathan Cirillo, Canadian Soldier Killed in Attack, Returns Home
item.description: A motorcade took Corporal Cirillo back to Hamilton, Ontario. A military funeral is to take place next week.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN
item.media:description: Kathy Cirillo, the mother of Cpl. Nathan Cirillo, followed pallbearers carrying her son's coffin on Friday in Ottawa.

item.title: DealBook: Investors Are Eager for African Sovereign Debt, Despite Plenty of Risks
item.description: Sub-Saharan countries have raised nearly $7 billion this year, more than in all of 2013, and yields on many bonds have fallen, even with the Ebola outbreak.
item.category: Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies
item.dc:creator: By DANNY HAKIM
item.media:description: The Kigali Convention Center in Rwanda under construction in April.

item.title: Japan Leader Faces Crisis Over Minister for Trade
item.description: Potentially damaging revelations surrounding the minister and one of his aides have added to pressure on Prime Minister Shinzo Abe.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Stars Backing Hong Kong Protests Pay Price on Mainland
item.description: Artists backing the pro-democracy movement are being punished by fans and companies in mainland China, on whose support many of their careers depend.
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN and ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Pro-democracy demonstrators on Friday in a tent city in Hong Kong. Artists who have supported them have faced boycotts.
